comments.author: Jaclyn
comments.content: Hello! this salad looks so fresh! great food architecture too! If you like you can submit your healthy food photos to: http://www.healthfreakfood.com it's sort of like tastespotting but for the health community, check it out!

comments.author: Morgan
comments.content:
This is amazing! I would never think to combine some of these things, but when I look at the dish they seem to work so well together.

You could totally be a chef at a high-class restaurant if you wanted to. Not that being an engineer isn't awesome too, of course.

comments.author: Francie
comments.content: Such a fun idea about dipping the grapes in the powder!

comments.author: buy ghost chili
comments.content: Haha I was thinking the same thing :)

comments.author: Silky Sienna
comments.content: Hi! I just happened to have a couple boxes of this very Alpine apple cider mix on hand, so I had to give this salad concept a try. I forgot the black olives at the market, and as I had just been picking violets in the woods this morning, I added a few of those. I would not have time to locate the isomalt. My other adaptations produced the following: Avocado/lime square, topped with tangerine and pink grapefruit segments. 4 thin slices of plum. 1 plump fresh blackberry. 3 violet petals, fresh picked garden thyme, two peeled green grapes, one on a pile of Alpine apple cider powder. (I forgot to add the tomato guts) A drizzle of olive/canola oil and sprinkling of sea salt. For the smokey flavor, I ventured a scant dusting of smoked paprika. Interesting, but not recommended. If I work this out further, I will add my rendition to my salad blog with pics, at http://www.salad-a-day.com Thanks for the idea and the amazing structure, surprising flavors and textures. So pretty!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: I'm so glad you gave this a shot, and you adaptations sound great! Let me know when you post your version, I'd love to see it.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content:
Oh, I see it is up now. Nice job!

I'm so glad you gave this a shot, and you adaptations sound great! Let me know when you post your version, I'd love to see it.

comments.author: Silky Sienna
comments.content: Thanks - I also posted pic on my Facebook and got many compliments from friends, then had to confess I copied! I will try this again, this time staying closer to your recipe.
